Fig. 1 Catalytic performance of aerobic oxidation of HMF over various Co-N-C/C catalysts in a base-free environment. Reaction conditions: HMF = 0.8 mmol, Catalyst = 200 mg, DMSO/H2O = 10 mL, Temperature = 90 °C, Pressure (O2) = 10 bar, Time = 15 h. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Effect of pyrolysis temperature of Co-N-C/C catalysts on the base-free HMF oxidation. Reaction conditions: HMF = 0.8 mmol, Catalyst = 200 mg, DMSO/H2O = 10 mL, Temperature = 90 °C, Pressure (O2) = 10 bar, Time = 15 h. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 (a) XRD patterns of Co-N-C/C samples prepared at different pyrolysis temperatures. (b) Comparison of XRD patterns of fresh and acid treated Co-N-C/C-800 catalysts. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Catalytic performance comparison of fresh and acid treated Co-N-C/C-800 catalyst. Reaction conditions: HMF = 0.8 mmol, Catalyst = 200 mg, DMSO/H2O = 10 mL, Temperature = 90 °C, Pressure (O2) = 10 bar, Time = 15 h. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Structural characterizations of Co-N-C/C-700, Co-N-C/AC-800 and Co-N-C/C-900 (a-c) STEM-dark field images (d-f) Corresponding metal Particle Size Distribution of catalysts (g-k) HR-TEM-bright field images of Co-N-C/C-800 catalyst (l-n) Elemental mapping of Co-N-C/C-800 catalyst. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 HAADF-STEM Images of (a,b) Fresh Co-N-C/C-800 catalyst (c,d) Acid Treated Co-N-C/C-800 catalyst. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 XPS (a) N 1s (b) Co 2p spectra of Co-N-C/C-800 catalyst. The production of 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA), a promising biodegradable alternative to fossil-based terephthalic acid (PTA), from biomass-derived 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) is of significant importance. A major challenge is to develop an effective non-precious metal catalyst system that does not require a homogeneous base. In this study, we present a noble-metal-free Co-N-C catalyst, derived from the pyrolysis of cobalt-phenanthroline complexes on a carbon support. This catalyst demonstrates exceptional performance, achieving a FDCA yield of 99.9 % and maintaining reusability for up to five catalytic cycles in the base-free oxidation of HMF to FDCA under mild conditions. Through controlled experiments and comprehensive characterizations, we propose that the active sites in the Co-N-C catalyst are Co single atoms bonded to nitrogen within graphitic sheets. This approach provides valuable insights into the exact nature of the active sites in such noble-metal-free M-N-C catalysts designed for biomass conversion Graphical abstract Noble metal free Co-N-C/C catalyst with Co-single atom as active sites for base-free aerobic oxidation of HMF to FDCA under mild conditions. Noble metal free Co-N-C/C catalyst with Co-single atom as active sites for base-free aerobic oxidation of HMF to FDCA under mild conditions. Image, graphical abstract Keywords 2,5-Furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) Biomass conversion Noble-metal-free Co-N-C catalyst Base-free oxidation Single atom active sites Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The sustainable production of chemicals from renewable biomass is an important strategy to realize carbon neutrality. Among the various transformations, the aerobic oxidation offers a promising approach for converting biomass-derived chemicals into valuable products while utilizing molecular oxygen as a benign oxidant [1-3]. A notable reaction within this realm is the oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) to 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA), which is a pivotal step in producing bio-based materials with enhanced sustainability [4-7]. HMF is primarily derived from the dehydration of sugars in biomass (Fig. S1). It serves as a critical intermediate in the production of various bio-based chemicals due to its high reactivity and functional group versatility [8-10]. The oxidation of HMF to FDCA is particularly noteworthy because FDCA is a key monomer for the production of polyethylene furanoate (PEF), a promising alternative to conventional petrochemical-based polymers due to its superior mechanical properties and reduced environmental impact [11-13]. Furthermore, the U.S. Department of Energy lists FDCA as one of the top 12 high-value compounds derived from biomass [14]. Thus, efficient catalysts for the oxidation of HMF to FDCA are essential for advancing the field of bio-based chemicals. The oxidation of HMF to produce FDCA involves complex chemical pathways and several intermediates, including 2,5-diformylfuran (DFF), 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (HMFCA) and 5-formylfurancarboxylic acid (FFCA), which pose a challenge in terms of catalytic selectivity (Scheme 1 ) [15-18]. Traditionally, the oxidation of HMF has been catalyzed by precious metals such as gold and platinum, which, despite their high efficiency and effectiveness, are associated with high costs and sustainability concerns [19]. In response to these challenges, recent research has increasingly focused on developing non-precious metal catalysts as viable alternatives. Non-precious metals present a cost-effective and environmentally sustainable option for catalysis. Among these, cobalt-based catalysts have attained significant attention due to their favourable properties and versatile catalytic behaviour [17,20-26]. Table S1 provides an overview of existing research on cobalt-based catalysts for the selective oxidation of HMF to FDCA. It is evident from the summary that cobalt catalysts typically require harsh reaction conditions such as high temperatures and elevated O₂ pressures or the presence of substantial amounts of base to achieve high yields of FDCA. The use of bases such as Na₂CO₃, NaBr, NaHCO₃, and KHCO₃ has been shown to enhance the conversion of HMF and improve FDCA yields. For instance, Yang et al. demonstrated that using Na₂CO₃ as a base, enabled complete conversion of HMF with a 96 % FDCA yield over a (Co1→ Cop)/NCNTs relay catalyst. However, their approach required an equal molar quantity of Na₂CO₃ relative to HMF (0.5 mmol), which not only increased the process cost but also diminished its environmental sustainability [17]. Similarly, Jain et al. reported a 80 % FDCA yield using a nanocrystalline spinel Li2CoMn3O8 catalyst in acetic acid medium at 150 °C and 55 bar O2 pressure in the presence of NaBr base [21]. Despite these advances, achieving high yields of FDCA under base-free conditions remains a crucial goal from both economic and environmental perspectives. Recent efforts to develop cobalt-based catalysts that operate under base-free conditions have shown promise but still face limitations. For example, Yang et al. achieved 100 % HMF conversion with a 72.4 % FDCA yield in a base-free environment at 120 °C [27]. Additionally, Tirsoaga et al. reported 96.6 % HMF conversion and a 93.2 % FDCA yield using a Co@Nb@MNP catalyst under base-free conditions at 100 °C [25]. However, both studies utilized tert‑butyl hydroperoxide (T-BuOOH) as the oxidant, which is costly and unsuitable for large-scale industrial processes. In our previous work, we demonstrated that the γ-Al₂O₃-supported Fe-N-C single-atom catalyst exhibited high activity and selectivity for the base-free aerobic oxidation of HMF to FDCA at 110 °C and 40 bar O2 [28]. Nevertheless, the use of γ-Al₂O₃ support may raise concerns on the long-term stability since FDCA is a relatively strong acid and may destruct the pore structure of γ-Al₂O₃ support. Compared to alumina, carbon is highly resistant to acids and possesses abundant pores and large surface areas, and therefore is a more practical choice for supporting metal single atom catalysts used in this reaction. On the other hand, in our earlier work [29], we found that Co-N-C single atom catalyst was able to activate oxygen and highly active for the aerobic oxidative cross-coupling of primary and secondary alcohols. Motivated by these earlier studies, we envision that carbon-supported Co-N-C catalyst might be active for the base-free aerobic oxidation of HMF to FDCA. To the best of our knowledge, there has been no earlier reports on the use of Co-N-C single atom catalyst for this reaction under base-free conditions. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemical reagents All the reagents in this study were commercialized and used as received without any further treatment. Cobalt Acetate ((CH3CO2)2Co, Purity: 98 %) was purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology, Shanghai, China. Carbon black (Vulcan XC-72R) was purchased from Cabot corporation chemicals Co., Ltd. 1,10-phenanthroline (Purity: ≥99 %) from Tianjin Kemiou Chemical Reagent Company Limited, Tianjin, China. Aforementioned all chemicals were used for preparation of catalysts. Chemical reagents applied for catalytic reaction are; 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF, Purity: >99 %) was purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology, Shanghai, China. Dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO Purity: 99.5 %) from Damao chemical Reagent, oxygen gas (O2, Purity: 99.9 %) was purchased from Dalian Kerui Gas Co., Ltd. Commercialized oxidation products for this reaction were also purchased for standard curves. 2,5-diformyl-furan (DFF, Purity: 98 %) was purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical company Limited, 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furan carboxylic acid (HMFCA, Purity: 98.93 %) from Ark Pharm, 5-formyl-2-furan carboxylic acid (FFCA, Purity: 98 %) from bide pharm and 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA, Purity: 98 %) from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology, Shanghai, China. 2.2 Synthesis of Co-N-C/C catalyst The Co-N-C/C catalysts, with a theoretical cobalt loading ranging from 1 to 10 wt%, were prepared using a pyrolysis method based on our earlier report [29]. The process involved the use of 1,10-phenanthroline as the nitrogen ligand to form a Co(phen)x complex. Specifically, Co(OAc)₂ and 1,10-phenanthroline (phen) in a 1:3 molar ratio were dispersed in ethanol and stirred for 30–40 min at room temperature. Carbon powder (VULCAN® XC72R) was then added to the mixture, which was subsequently refluxed at 60 °C for 15 h with magnetic stirring at 500 rpm. After cooling to room temperature, ethanol was gradually removed using a rotary evaporator. The resulting solid was dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C for 12 h, then ground into a fine powder using a mortar and pestle. This powder was transferred to a quartz tube furnace for pyrolysis, which was carried out at temperatures of 700 °C, 800 °C, and 900 °C for 2 h under an argon (Ar) atmosphere, with a heating rate of 2 °C/min, and then cooled to room temperature. The resulting dark grey solid, designated as Co-N-C/C catalyst, was used for subsequent HMF oxidation reactions (Fig. S2). For acid treatment of catalysts the prepared Co-N-C/C catalyst was treated with a 1 M nitric acid (HNO₃) solution. Initially, a sample of the Co-N-C/C catalyst was immersed in the 1 M HNO₃ solution at room temperature for a duration of 12 h. During this period, the mixture was continuously stirred to ensure comprehensive interaction between the nitric acid and the catalyst. After the treatment, the catalyst was carefully filtered and washed with 0.5 M NaOH solution to eliminate any residual acid and then washed multiple times with ultrapure water until the pH of the filtrate reached neutral (pH = 7). Finally, the washed catalyst was then dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C for 12 h to obtain the acid-treated sample. 2.3 Characterization of catalysts 2.3.1 Scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) STEM and High angle annular dark-field (HAADF) STEM images were obtained on a JEOL JEM-ARM200F microscope operated at an acceleration voltage of 200 kV with a guaranteed resolution of 0.08 nm. Before this characterization, the catalysts samples were suspended in ethanol and dispersed ultrasonically. Then drops of prepared suspension were applied onto the copper grids covered with lacy carbon films and finally dried at room temperature. Elemental mapping and energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) layered images were obtained on X-MAXN 80 T IE-250 instrument. 2.3.2 X-ray diffraction (XRD) Crystalline phases of catalysts were identified by XRD analysis which was performed on a PANalytical X'pert PRO x-ray diffractometer equipped with a Cu Kα radiation source (λ = 1.58418 Å) and a nickel filter. Beam voltage was operated at 40 kV and 40 mA and diffractograms were recorded with scanning angle (2θ) domain of 10° to 90° along with measured rate of 0.02° per second sampling interval. PANalytical X'pert High Score and JADE software were used for analyzing the data. JCPDS database was used to interpret the diffractograms. 2.3.3 N2 adsoption-desorption The textural properties of the calcined catalyst samples were identified from N2 adsoption-desoption isotherms which were obtained at −196 °C using a Micromeritics ASAP 2460 instrument. To determine the pore size distribution, the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method was used while the t-plot approach was used to compute the pore volumes. Prior to the measurements, the samples were degassed overnight with N2 flow at 200 °C and 1 mTorr to ensure a relatively clean surface. Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface areas were calculated from adsorption isotherm data within the equilibrium pressure range of 0.05<P/Po<0.3. 2.3.4 Temperature programmed desorption 2.3.4.1 CO2-TPD The measurements regarding basic sites distribution and surface basicity of catalysts were analyzed by temperature programed desorption of CO2 (CO2-TPD). Micrometrics Autochem II 2920 instrument was used coupled with MS detector. To perform the CO2 TPD experiments, firstly catalyst samples were put in a quartz reactor of TPD instrument and pretreated under 30 mL/min flow of He gas at 400 °C for 2 h, then allowed it to cool down at 50 °C. Secondly, the CO2 adsorption step was carried out at 50 °C by feeding 100 %CO2 (50 mL/min) flow until saturation. Then the sample chamber was flushed out with He for 60 min to remove the weakly adsorbed CO2 from the catalytic surface. After the base line of MS signal became steady, the CO2 desorption was performed from 50 to 850 °C with heating temperature ramp of 10 °C/min and finally desorbed CO2 was monitored at MS detector. Effluent curves of desorbed CO2 (m/z = 44) were recorded and are known as CO2-TPD curves. 2.3.5 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements was carried out on a Thermo Scientific ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer equipped with an Al anode (Al Kα = 1846.6 eV). The background pressure in the analysis chamber was lower than 1 × 10–8 Pa, and the operating pressure was around 1.5 × 10–5 Pa. The survey and spectra were acquired at a pass-energy of 30 eV. The binding energy (B.E.) calibration was adjusted bases on a reference peak of C 1 s transition appeared at 284.6 eV. 2.4 Base-free oxidation of HMF The base-free aerobic oxidation of HMF to FDCA was conducted in a 50 mL stainless steel high-pressure autoclave, which was equipped with an internal temperature controller and a pressure gauge. A schematic representation of the reaction system is shown in Fig. S3. Initially, a solvent mixture of dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) and ultra-pure water in a 50:50 ratio was prepared by combining DMSO and water in a 100 mL volumetric flask. This dual solvent system has proved to be very promising for base-free HMF oxidation, in our recently published work [28]. Typically, for the reaction, HMF (0.8 mmol), catalyst (200 mg), and 10 mL of the solvent mixture were placed in a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was then sealed tightly and purged with N2 gas multiple times to remove any impurities as well as to check the gas leakage. Finally, the oxygen (O2) gas was introduced as an oxidant after purging it three times from the reactor at required pressure (10 bar). After checking the gas leakage, the reactor was heated to the target temperature (typically 90 °C) to initiate the oxidation reaction along with vigorous magnetic stirring at 700 rpm to prevent mass transfer limitations. The temperature was then gradually increased from room temperature (20 °C) to 90 °C at a rate of 1 °C/min. When the temperature reached to desired temperature, that time was considered as starting point (t = 0) for oxidation reaction. Once the reaction time was complete, the reactor was cooled to room temperature by removing it from the heating source, quickly quenched in an ice water bath, and carefully depressurized. The solid catalyst was recovered by centrifugation, washed several times with ultra-pure water, and dried at 60 °C for future use. The liquid product was separated using PTFE (0.2 µm) syringe filters and stored in a refrigerator for subsequent analysis. 2.5 Product analysis The liquid products were analyzed using a high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) system (Agilent 1200 series) equipped with a refractive index (R.I.) detector and a Rezex ROA-Organic Acid H +column (300 mm × 7.8 mm × 9 µm). A 5 mM H2SO4 solution was used as the mobile phase at 45 °C of column temperature with a flow rate of 0.5 mL/min. Product quantification was performed using an external standard method. Reactants, products, and intermediates were calibrated using authenticated standards at specific retention times. HMF conversion was calculated as the molar percentage of HMF transformed into products, while product selectivity was defined as the molar percentage of each product relative to the converted HMF. The formulas for calculating HMF conversion, product selectivity, and yield are as follows: H M F C o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = n H M F , 0 − n H M F , t n H M F , 0 × 100 P r o d u c t S e l e c t i v i t y ( % ) = n p r o d u c t n H M F , 0 − n H M F , t × 100 P r o d u c t Y i e l d ( % ) = n p r o d u c t n H M F , 0 × 100 where n represents the number of moles at the initial time (0) and final time (t). Each reaction was conducted at least twice to ensure reproducibility. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance for base-free HMF oxidation A series of Co catalysts with varying Co loadings were prepared by impregnation of carbon with Co(phen)x complexes, followed by pyrolysis at 700∼900 °C in Ar atmosphere. The resulting catalysts were then evaluated for their ability to catalyze the base-free oxidation of HMF under mild conditions (90 °C, 10 bar O2, 15 h). As shown in (Table S1, entry 1), the oxidation of HMF to FDCA cannot spontaneously proceed in the absence of the catalyst. In a preliminary experiment using a bare carbon support pyrolyzed at 800 °C, only minimal catalytic activity was observed, yielding 6.8 % FDCA yield with a 16.7 % conversion of HMF (Table S1, entry 2). These results indicated that the pyrolyzed carbon support cannot efficiently catalyze the conversion of HMF to FDCA. Fig. 1 illustrates the catalytic performance of various Co-N-C catalysts for base-free HMF oxidation. It can be seen that the conversion of HMF was directly proportional to the amount of cobalt, increasing with higher Co loadings. The catalyst with 7 % Co loading exhibited the highest activity, achieving a 99.9 % conversion of HMF. However, beyond this optimal loading, HMF conversion decreased from 99.9 % to 88.3 %. This decline may be attributed to the aggregation of cobalt nanoparticles which will be addressed in the following section. In parallel with HMF conversion, the product selectivity also increased with Co loading and attained a maximum of 99.9 % at 7 % Co loading. However, further increasing the Co loading to 10 % resulted in a reduced FDCA yield of 81.2 %, with a minor amount of FFCA (2.5 %) detected. These results indicate that the Co-N-C/C catalyst with 7 % cobalt loading is the most effective catalytic system for HMF oxidation to FDCA under base-free conditions. When compared with other Co-based catalysts reported in literature (Table S2), it is evident that our 7Co-N-C/C offers the best performance in terms of activity and FDCA selectivity without any base additive. Similar to the effect of Co loadings, the pyrolysis temperature for preparation of the Co-N-C/C catalysts also imposed a remarkable influence on the catalytic performance [30]. As shown in Fig. 2 , initially, the FDCA yield increased substantially from 35.9 % to 99.9 % as the pyrolysis temperature was raised from 700 °C to 800 °C. However, this yield decreased to 89.1 % when the temperature was further increased to 900 °C. The performance deterioration at 900 °C is likely due to the aggregation of cobalt particles during the high-temperature pyrolysis. This phenomenon was corroborated by XRD and TEM analyses presented in the characterization section. 3.2 Characterization and investigation of active sites in Co-N-C/C catalysts To investigate the catalyst structure responsible for the high activity and selectivity of the Co-N-C/C catalyst, control experiments were designed and conducted followed by extensive characterizations using ICP, XRD, STEM-DF, STEM-BF, HAADF-STEM, and XPS techniques. Table 1 summarizes the physico-chemical properties of the Co-N-C/C catalysts prepared at different pyrolysis temperatures. The actual Co loadings determined by ICP, are also included, indicating the variation in FDCA yield (Fig. 2) was not due to the difference in metal loading. The N2-adsorption and desorption isotherms (Fig. S4) indicated that the Co-N-C/C-800 catalyst exhibited a superior BET surface area of 170.1 m²/g compared to the Co-N-C/C-700 catalyst (110.4 m²/g) and was nearly equivalent to the Co-N-C/C-900 catalyst (177.2 m²/g). Additionally, the BJH pore size distribution analysis showed that the Co-N-C/C-800 catalyst had the largest average pore diameter (6.9 nm) (Table 1). This increase in specific surface area, along with a significant number of mesopores, enhances the accessibility of metal active sites and mitigates diffusion constraints. The XRD patterns of fresh catalysts, presented in Fig. 3 (a), primarily indicate the presence of metallic Co, with only faint indications of CoOx or CoNx species. The increased sharpness and intensity of metallic Co reflections with higher pyrolysis temperatures, especially at or above 800 °C, suggest notable sintering of metallic Co particles. Despite this, the catalyst pyrolyzed at 800 °C exhibited the best performance, implying that metallic Co nanoparticles may not be the primary active centers (Fig. S5). To further investigate the catalytic role of metallic Co or CoOx nanoparticles, acid-leaching experiment was conducted for the Co-N-C/C-800 sample. After acid treatment, the Co content decreased from 4.2 wt% to 3.4 wt% (determined by ICP). The acid treatment removed Co-containing species and the sharp XRD reflections of metallic Co almost vanished (Fig. 3(b)). Nevertheless, the activity of the acid-treated Co-N-C/C catalyst remained almost unchanged (Fig. 4 ). These results suggest that the XRD-detectable Co0 and CoOx/CoNx nanoparticles likely play a minimal role in catalysis. This observation prompts a reconsideration of the pyrolysis process. It is known that transition metals can facilitate the graphitization of carbon [29,31], and we propose that the XRD-detectable Co nanoparticles may be largely encapsulated in graphitic nanoshells that protect them from being accessible by HMF. The true active species may be those non-detectable by XRD, like Co-N-C single atom species. To verify our assumption and to better understand the influence of pyrolysis temperature on the reactivity of Co-catalysts, the structural properties of representative catalysts treated at 700, 800, and 900 °C were characterized using STEM imaging. As illustrated in Fig. 5 , the size of the metal nanoparticles (NPs) increased with increase in pyrolysis temperatures due to the Ostwald ripening effect. The spot scan spectra and corresponding elemental map spectrums confirmed that the visible NPs (Fig. 5 (a-c)) on the carbon support are metal Co, and the N element is uniformly dispersed within the carbon matrix ((Fig. S6-S8). The average particle sizes were 11.4, 20.82, and 38.45 nm for Co-N-C/C-700, Co-N-C/C-800, and Co-N-C/C-900, respectively (Fig. 5(d-f)). In contrast to Co-N-C/C-800, the decrease in activity for Co-N-C/C-900 (from 99.9 % to 89.1 %), as depicted in Fig. 2, can be attributed primarily to the significant aggregation of Co species. The enlarged HR-TEM image shown in Fig. 5(g) represents bigger Co NPs. It was obtained using a 200 keV electron beam that travelled parallel to the [011] zine axis of the crystalline Co NP over the optimum under-defocus conditions. The lattice spacings (111) and (200) of Co with characteristic acute angle of 55° were identified based on the JCPDS card (PDF#15–0806) (Fig. 5h). The results from HR-TEM are well consistent with the structure analysis from the fast Fourier transform (FFT) and aforementioned XRD results. Additionally, Energy-Dispersive X-ray Spectroscopy (EDX) revealed that the carbon nanoshells are composed of C, N and O. To identify the true active sites of the Co-N-C catalysts as well as to gain insight into the fine structure of Co-NPs, the aberration-corrected HAADF-STEM imaging was conducted. The HAADF-STEM images of acid-treated Co-N-C/C-800 indicated a significant reduction in the number of nanoparticles compared to the fresh samples (Fig. 6 (a,c)), and the residual Co NPs were all totally encapsulated by carbon layers of around 4–5 nm thick (Fig. S9). We propose that the Co nanoparticles in these samples are probably inaccessible to reactants and may merely act as spectators in the catalytic process, with other species likely contributing to the observed catalytic activity. More importantly, HAADF-STEM images depicted that besides large Co nanoparticles encapsulated in graphitic nano-shells, a significant number of uniformly dispersed Co single atoms are visible within the graphitic sheets of both the fresh and acid-treated catalysts (Fig. 6 (b,d)). Taking it into account that the catalytic performance after the acid treatment remained unchanged, it is reasonable to deduce that a great number of Co single atoms in both the fresh and acid-treated samples should function as the active sites for the base-free aerobic oxidation of HMF to FDCA (Fig. S10). The resistance to acid leaching and durability of Co single atoms against aggregation during pyrolysis at 800 °C suggest that these single atoms are strongly bonded to N or C atoms within the graphitic sheets. To elucidate the chemical state of these Co single atoms, we conducted XPS on the Co-N-C/C-800 catalyst. As illustrated in Fig. 7 (a), the high resolution N 1s XPS spectra reveal that the incorporated N atoms are predominantly in pyridinic (398.7 eV) and pyrrolic (400.4 eV) forms. [32,33] It should be noted that pyridinic nitrogen or pyrrolic nitrogen could be considered the primary ligand coordinating with the Co single atoms which significantly contribute to the enhancement of catalytic activity. Consistent with the N 1s XPS results, the Co 2p spectra (Fig. 7(b)) show two prominent peaks at 780.8 eV and 796.5 eV, corresponding to Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 species, respectively, which can be attributed to Co2+ species [34,35]. The presence of satellite peaks at 785.0 eV and 802.9 eV confirmed that the surface is predominated by Co2+. Moreover, no metallic Co0 species was detected by XPS, which well aligns with the HAADF-STEM imaging result that large Co0 nanoparticles were encapsulated by thick carbon layers. Even if there are Co0 nanoparticles exposed on the surface, they are subject to oxidation on the surface forming Co0@Co2+ core@shell structure, which makes Co0 undetectable by XPS. The high-resolution C 1s spectrum (Fig. S11 (a)) was deconvoluted into four peaks at 284.4 eV, 285.5 eV, 288.9 eV and 291.1 eV which are well attributed to C = C, C–N, C–O bonds and the C = O group respectively [32,33,35]. The presence of the C–N bond confirms the effective doping of N into the carbon matrix [36]. The O 1s XPS spectra, featuring peaks centered at 531.9 eV and 533.3 eV, attributed to adsorbed oxygen-containing species [23,37,38], did not show significant amounts of cobalt oxide surface layers (which would appear at 529.2 eV) in the Co-N-C/C-800 catalysts (Fig. S11 (b)). It can be concluded that the Co species detectable by XPS primarily consist of Co single atoms bonded to N atoms within the graphitic sheets. Temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) of CO2 was conducted to investigate the influence of Co-N-C on the surface basicity of catalysts (Fig. 8 ). According to desorption temperatures or chemical bond strength, basic sites can be categorized into weak (T < 200 °C), medium (T = 200 – 400 °C) and strong (T > 400 °C) [39]. The Co-N-C/C catalysts, subjected to different pyrolysis temperatures, exhibit additional CO2 desorption peaks, signifying the formation of new basic sites with varying strengths due to the incorporation of cobalt and nitrogen doped carbon. For all three Co-N-C/C catalysts, significant desorption peaks are observed above 400 °C, which are attributed to the presence of strong basic sites [40]. The amount of surface basicity, quantified by integrating the MS 44 signal (Table 1), shows that it gradually decreases from 57.4 μmol/g to 32.1 μmol/g with the increase in pyrolysis temperature from 700 to 900 °C. The basicity is associated with the surface pyridinic N species whose amount also decreases with the increase in the pyrolysis temperature. It has been demonstrated that tuning the basicity of carbon surface is an effective strategy for enhancing the oxidation of HMF to FDCA [3]. Therefore, it can be claimed that addition of Co, N-doped carbon and pyrolysis at 800 °C results in the formation of strong basic sites, which should play a significant role in dehydrogenation step during HMF oxidation to FDCA. Nevertheless, basicity is not a determining factor. The Co-N-C/C-700 catalyst, which possesses the most basic sites, had the lowest FDCA yield. Instead, the single-atom structure of Co-N-C, which heavily relies on the pyrolysis temperature [41,42] should play a major role in determining the activity for HMF oxidation to FDCA. 3.3 Reaction route analysis To understand the selective adsorption of HMF over Co-N-C/C catalyst and to elucidate the reaction pathway, kinetic experiment was conducted at variable reaction times and the results are illustrated in Fig. 9 . The data reveal that HMF is consumed rapidly within the first two hours, with complete conversion achieved after 15 h of reaction time. The process yields 99.9 % of FDCA with 100 % carbon balance, indicating highly efficient transformation. Notably, the activation of CO and C = O plays a dominant role and the only two intermediates, FFCA and DFF are detected during the reaction process, while HMFCA is not detected. Therefore, the reasonable reaction route of HMF oxidation over Co-N-C/C follows route A (Scheme 1) via the formation of DFF and FFCA intermediates, as depicted in Fig. S12. The reaction profile indicates that the yield of DFF increases during the initial two hours but gradually decreases in the later stages of the reaction. This behavior is consistent with the reaction pathways observed for other non-noble metal oxides, such as MnOx-CeO2 and Fe3O4 CoOx [38,43], as well as noble metal catalysts like Ru/C and Au/Pd-CNT [44,45]. This reaction pathway can be attributed to the selective adsorption of the hydroxyl (-OH) group of HMF on the basic and positively charged surface of the Co-N-C/C catalyst. During the reaction, cobalt facilitates the oxidation of the hydroxyl group (-OH) to form an aldehyde group (-CHO), which is then further oxidized to a carboxyl group (-COOH). The rapid conversion of HMF to DFF and FFCA indicates a swift initial reaction phase, while the subsequent conversion of -CHO to -COOH occurs more slowly, necessitating up to 15 h for completion. Based on the aforementioned results and reported work in the literature, a plausible reaction mechanism for HMF oxidation over the Co-N-C/C catalyst is proposed and illustrated in Fig. 10 . Firstly, the HMF substrate is adsorbed on the Co-N-C structure due to the surface basicity of the catalyst via oxygen atom in the hydroxyl group forming intermediate 1 (IM-1) and releasing proton (H +) at the same time. In the presence of oxygen (O2), IM-1 undergoes β-H elimination and oxidative elimination to yield DFF [46,47]. The conversion of the aldehyde group to a carboxylic acid then occurs through a hemiacetal or geminal-diol intermediate (IM-2), followed by further oxidative dehydrogenation aided by basic sites of the catalyst to produce FFCA. Through a similar mechanism via IM-3, oxidation of aldehyde moiety in FFCA is finally transformed into FDCA. During the whole process, O2 plays an indirect role to remove protons from catalyst surface [20]. It should be noted that reactive oxygen species, can be generated through the adsorption and activation of O2 molecules at the single-atom Co-Nx sites in Co-N-C/C catalyst [29]. 3.4 Reusability of Co-N-C/C catalyst The ability to reuse a catalyst multiple times without experiencing significant degradation in performance is a critical factor for its viability in large-scale industrial applications. This attribute is particularly important in processes where minimizing waste and reducing operational costs are key considerations. To assess this aspect of the Co-N-C/C catalyst, its recyclability was thoroughly tested, and the results are depicted in Fig. 11 . The HMF conversion and FDCA yield remained almost constant after five catalytic runs, indicating the excellent stability of the Co-N-C/C catalyst for HMF oxidation. Moreover, metal aggregation and oxidation of Co were not observed from the XRD patterns of the recycled catalysts (Fig. S13). Surface areas for both fresh and recycled catalysts (170 m2 g-1 and 168 m2 g-1, respectively) did not significantly change according to BET isotherms (Fig. S14). This stability in surface area suggests that the catalyst's active sites remained accessible and effective throughout the recycling process. Furthermore, HAADF-STEM images (Fig. S10 (e,f)) indicated that the atomic dispersion of Co species is well preserved after five catalytic runs. The combination of these results demonstrates that the Co-N-C/C catalyst not only maintains its catalytic activity and selectivity over multiple cycles but also upholds its structural and chemical stability, making it an excellent candidate for industrial applications. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, we have developed a straight forward approach for synthesizing Co-N-C/C catalysts which is composed of both Co nanoparticles and single atoms. The catalyst obtained at pyrolysis temperature of 800 °C achieves the highest FDCA yield of 99.9 % and exhibits outstanding reusability for the base-free oxidation of HMF to FDCA under mild reaction conditions. Our extensive data from various control experiments and comprehensive characterizations confirm that the Co single atoms, bonded to nitrogen within graphitic sheets, are the active species responsible for this high performance, whereas the Co nanoparticles encapsulated by carbon nanoshells act as spectators. The enhanced surface basicity due to incorporation of pyridinic nitrogen was confirmed by CO2 TPD which further led to increase in adsorption and transformation of HMF molecules to FDCA. Reusability tests also showed a negligible loss in the catalytic activity and limited change in structural and surface properties upon five consecutive runs of HMF oxidation reaction. Overall, this study not only advances the development of efficient and durable single-atom catalysts for fine chemical synthesis but also provides valuable insights into the precise nature of the active sites in noble-metal-free M-N-C catalysts for base-free aerobic oxidation of HMF to FDCA under mild conditions. coredata.dc:description: The production of 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA), a promising biodegradable alternative to fossil-based terephthalic acid (PTA), from biomass-derived 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) is of significant importance. A major challenge is to develop an effective non-precious metal catalyst system that does not require a homogeneous base. In this study, we present a noble-metal-free Co-N-C catalyst, derived from the pyrolysis of cobalt-phenanthroline complexes on a carbon support. This catalyst demonstrates exceptional performance, achieving a FDCA yield of 99.9 % and maintaining reusability for up to five catalytic cycles in the base-free oxidation of HMF to FDCA under mild conditions. Through controlled experiments and comprehensive characterizations, we propose that the active sites in the Co-N-C catalyst are Co single atoms bonded to nitrogen within graphitic sheets. This approach provides valuable insights into the exact nature of the active sites in such noble-metal-free M-N-C catalysts designed for biomass conversion

coredata.dc:title: Co-N-C catalyst with single atom active sites for base-free aerobic oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural to 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid under mild conditions
